titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: The storm deprived me of my usual daily exercise— My Son with his two Sons Charles, and Henry dined with us—

The Storm subsided without a clearing off— The Reverend R. C. Waterston Pastor of the Church of the Saviour Bedford Street Boston, who married a daughter of Josiah Quincy preached by exchange with Mr. Lunt— In the morning from John 18.38. “What is truth”— And in the afternoon from Ezekiel 8.5. “Then said he unto me, Son of man, lift up thine eyes now the way towards the north— So I lifted up mine eyes the way towards the north, and, behold, northward, at the gate of the altar, this image of jealousy in the entry”— It was from the wonderful vision of Ezekiel, of which, the preacher gave a somewhat detailed exposition, quoting the Lines from Miltons Paradise Lost—

lg.l: “Ezekiel saw, when by the vision led his eye surveyed the dark

div.p: Mr. Waterston drew from the whole story a solemn and edifying lesson of morality— I invited him to dine with us, but he considered himself engaged at Mr. Quincys— I walked to Meeting in the morning, but rode the remainder of the way— My Son was here in the evening, but his wife was retained at home by the weather the copious rain coming on again this eveg.

From the long continued dampness of the atmosphere, or from my own imprudence in my diet, I had a very restless and almost sleepless night. I took advantage of an interval during which the rain held up for a short walk—

The weather cleared off and the summer returned— I had an indifferent night, sleepless and disquieted. I took a very short walk in the morning, and a ride to Mr. Bents Biscuit Bakery to Milton in the Evening— My Granddaughter was much indisposed this day. In the evening Elizabeth. C. Adams and Isaac Hull, were here with Edward Frothingham.

A warm and trying Summer day. After a restless and sleepless night, I was deprived of my walk and the portion of time which I could devote to any occupation, was spent in reading newspapers, Articles in Littell’s Living Age, and Beloes’ Herodotus. It serves the hour but leaves no impression I have got through with Clio—Euturpe, and Thalia, and half Melpomene— But this most ancient of Profane Historians seems rather a collector of Anecdotes than merely an Historian— A very small portion of the Anecdotes appear to have any foundation in fact, and they are all discredited by the perpetual occurence of the marvellous— There is also an inextricable confusion of names and the same persons, are mentioned by different names in Herodotus, Diodorus Seculus, Justin the Abbreviator of Trogus Pompeius whose work has perished, and the scriptures of the Old Testament. Chronology prior to the age of Alexander of Macedon is an inextricable chaos— The writings of David, of Solomon, and of Homer about twelve hundred years before Christ, stand unaccountable monuments of Literature in a
very high degree of improvement, with a subsequent period of at least seven hundred years, of total barbarism. The Psalms of David, the Proverbs of Solomon, and the Illyad and Oddissy of Homer are phenomena in the History of literature hitherto unexplained. and in all probability so to remain notwithstanding the recent discovery of the secret of Hierogliphical writing. Had visits from Mr. Loring of Hingham accompanied by Mr. Richard Smith of Philadelphia his wife and daughter. Mr. Smith recollects an acquaintance with us in 1811, when we resided at Saint Petersburgh in Russia— My Son gave me a check for one-hundred dollars upon the Merchants Bank at Boston. At half past eleven oclock this evening, Mrs. Hutchinson, wife of the man who lives with us as a farmer, was delivered of a Son—

Another sleepless night; succeeded by another fair, day, of very oppressive Summer heat. My Wife and Mrs. John Adams went with the carriage me into Boston— They, returned home to dinner— We rode this evening round Mt Wollaston and were much tormented by musquitos. There was a Convention of Teachers of the Primary School, held this day at the Stone Meeting House— While I was out riding a Committee from the Convention, called and told my wife that they wished to pay me a visit tomorrow in a body. For which she appointed ten oclock in the morning— The Reverend Dr. John Codman of Dorchester and his wife called also while I was out. In the Evening my Son passed an hour with us, but his wife was not with him.

I had a second almost totally sleepless night, and consequent weakness throughout the day. At nine this morning I rode to the Stone Bank, and deposited there a Check in the Merchants Bank Boston for one hundred dollars, given me by my Son— I drew also at the same time two Checks, drawn by myself on the Stone Bank one of one hundred dollars, in favor of Mrs. Mary. C. Adams, for our household expenses, and one of thirty dollars, in my own favor for the same purpose—both of which I received in small Bills. The hundred dollars I gave to Mary for the current daily expenses— At ten oclock the Teachers male and Female, of the Convention paid me their visit. and their presiding Officer made me a short Address, which I answered I know not how— One of them a Mr. Nathaniel Wolcott made inquiries respecting his Grandfather Oliver Wolcott— Another brought me a Letter from the Reverend Calvin Durfee, of South Dedham, and an Album in which he requested me to write some Lines. His name was Lemuel Shattock— A Mr. Bliss came afterwards alone—and I was requested to write out my Answer to the Address which had been made to me by them. I found this impossible and was only able to write a few Lines in the Album. Towards Evening I rode with my Wife and Mrs. John Adams to Braintree returning by the way of Milton— We had for evening visitors, Mr. Glück, Mr. Williams, Edward Frothingham, Isaac Hull, and John Quincy.
Mrs. Charles, my Son, and his son John Quincy were also here— At the close of the day I found myself much exhausted— This was the Birthday, of my Sons daughter Louisa Catherine, who is sixteen years old— She is now on a visit to Mrs. Sedgwick at Lenox.

I had fortunately a night of quiet sleep but found myself not so much after it as I had expected— Little if anything recruited in my strength and not at all in my Spirits. Mr. Shattock came for Mr. Durfee’s Album, in which I had written some lines and returned the Books to him without finishing them—nor had I been able to write out, my answer to the Address and very probably shall not be. Mr. Horace Mann, the School Commissioner delivered last evening an Address to the Convention in the Town Hall which I was invited to attend, but could not— The weather is still at Summer heat— The Brothers John Quincy and Joseph. H. Adams. were here— Joseph returned yesterday afternoon from a fortnight’s excursion, to Canada, Saratoga, and Utica. I received a Card of invitation from the President of Harvard University Edward Everett in behalf of the Corporation to the Exhibition and dinner in the Hall on Commencement Day the 25th. of this month— I received also a Letter from Robert Malone, dated Noxuba County Mississippi Somerville August 2d. making inquiries concerning Andrew Walker who in his last Will, claims to have served as
an Officer in the Pennsylvania Line through the War, and thereby to have become a member of the Cincinnati in the State of Pennsylvania. And he bequeaths, all his interest in the Funds of the said Cincinnati to his daughter Charlotte Walker to her Heirs and Assigns forever— Mr. Malone states that he had written to Philadelphia for the necessary information to enable the Executor of Andrew Walker to get the Funds if any, but was referred to me as more able to give the information than any other person. It is strange that I know not to whom excepting Joseph. B. Bird, to whom I could apply, to obtain this information— I received also a Pamphlet entitled the Daguerreotype a magazine of Foreign Literature and Science selected chiefly from the Periodical Publications of England France and Germany. 1847. Volume one, number one—Boston. Published by J. M. Whitemore—114. Washington Street, and addressed to me by the Authors. I rode in the Evening with my wife, Miss Louisa C. Smith and my Granddaughter Mary Louisa round Braintree—

Mr. Lunt preached this morning from Ephesians 2.12. Without God in the World and this afternoon from Matthew 20.26–27. Whosoever will be great among you let him be your minister. 27. And whosoever will be Chief among you, let him be your servant— In the Discourse of the morning Mr. Lunt remarked, that there were, among Men a much greater number who live without God in the World, than was generally
believed. That professed atheists were not very common; but that every person who manifested their disbelief, of the existence of a Supreme Being, to whom they were responsible for their lives upon Earth, must be held to live without God in the World— The Discourse of the Afternoon, was upon a more familiar Doctrine of Religious Morals. I walked to and from Church in the morning but rode in the afternoon. The weather is cool, and threatens and easterly storm— My Son was here in the Evening, with his Son Charles.

The weather continues cool, almost cold, so that I had a fire made this morning in my Bed chamber. I had a morning visit, from Mr. Edmund Chadwick a Clergyman from Bangor in the State of Maine; with whom I had, much conversation, particularly upon my translation of the Psalms. He requested of me an Autograph which I gave him— Mrs. Charles Adams went to Boston and was not here this day— We had a visit from Mr. Nathaniel Curtis of Roxbury and his wife— They came out to see Mr. Thomas Boylston who is living for the Summer at Board at French’s Tavern. As they did last Summer, but have not called upon us either then nor now— The eldest Son named Ward Nicholas, is residing with his Father, John Boylston, and his Family at the Princeton Estate— He has been educated as a Phycian and is called the Dr. but does not practise, and neither the Father or either of the sons follow any occupation whatever— They live upon the income left them by the Will of Mr. Ward Nicholas Boylston, and in nowise as a harmonious family— I took an Evening ride with my wife, and Mrs. John Adams— My Grandaughter Mary Louisa took an
afternoon ride on horseback— My Son was here in the Evening and the day closed with a cool evening—

I had a tolerable quiet night, but a somewhat uneasy morning. I had a fire again in my Bed chamber, but the morning soon cleared away to the temperature of Summer— I walked round the Railway Square, before noon— I took a ride about the time of Sunset with my Wife, and Mrs. Charles, and Louisa. C. Smith, to Braintree returning by the road through the Quarries. My Son and his wife were here in the Evening. Albert Putnam who has lived with us some time as Coachman gave notice to my Son, that he is about to leave us, and to go into business—

A half nights rest, and a half days walk before dinner. Mrs. Charles, and Elizabeth, went to a Tea Party at Mrs. Seaver’s in Dorchester. Mrs. John Adams, was quite ill, confined to her room. We had as evening visitors Mr. Josiah Quincy and his son in Law Mr. Waterston— Also Mr. Beale and his two daughters— My Son was also here— The Cambria a Steamer of the Cunard Line, arrived this day, after a passage of fourteen days, from Liverpool— The Missouri a vessel of the French Line of Steamers, recently put into operation the second of the line, has been so mismanaged that instead of making her destined Port of
of New York, seems to have missed her way, and brought in by the aid of other vessels to Halifax. There is another Line, called the American Line plying between New York and Bremen. Both these Lines are rivals to the Cunard Line, the only one that has hitherto been successful—

The last night, the change of Season, from the Summer to the Autumnal atmosphere took place, and with a brisk north west wind, I was enabled to take a morning walk of a mile and a half— I rode this Evening with Mrs. Charles Adams, Louisa C. Smith, and my Granddaughter Mary Louisa. Mrs. Charles Adams was here in the Evening.

I dined at my Sons with Mr. Alexander Vattemare, the twofold personage, as a Stage Player, and Ventriloquist, and as the projector, of Exchanges of Books, who was here, in the years 1840. and 41. and then returned to France, and has now made his second visit to this Country, bringing with him, it is said, almost 12000. volumes in Exchange, for other books to be collected from the Public Libraries of the scientific Institutions of the several States, and the Libraries of the State Legislatures— Just as we were about to sit down to Table, Mr. Filmore of Buffalo in the State of New York, came to pay me a visit and dined with us. Mr. Charles Brooks of Boston came also while we were at dinner. Mr. Vattemare appears to have lost none of his zeal and enthusiasm for his project and system of exchanging Books. He professes however, to have abdicated his second
character of Ventriloquist and stage Player— He is now, no longer Mr. Alexander but simply Mr. Vattemare— He and Mr. Filmore, returned to Boston by the Railroad Cars and both propose to leave the City tomorrow— I rode with Mrs. Charles Adams to Milton leaving Mr. George. T. Bigelow with my Son—

I had an indifferent nights rest, but took a walk this morning round the long Square. The past midshipman John Quincy, came to take leave, being ordered to Norfolk in Virginia, and the Lieut his brother has orders to repair to Charlestown— I rode after dinner with my Wife, Louisa. C. Smith and my Granddaughter Mary Louisa, round Milton Hill— Miss Mary E. E. Cutts, has been some time, at Mr Hubbards a member of Congress at Middletown Connecticut, and has promised to make us a visit, and was expected to arrive last evening— My Grandaughter went to Boston to meet her, but she did not come—

I had a restless and almost sleepless night. Mr. Amos Smith Colleague of Dr. Francis Parkman, as Minister of the new North Church Hanover Street Boston preached by Exchange with Mr. Lunt— morning text was from Matthew 10,31. “Ye are of more value than many Sparrows.” and the object of the Discourse was, to expatiate upon the value of man considered in the light of appreciath property
a subject somewhat singular, and novel in its character Mr. Smith dined with us and his afternoon Discourse was from Hebrews 12.2. “Looking unto Jesus, the author and finisher of our faith.” Returning from Meeting in the afternoon, in the evening I found Mr. De Grand here from Boston. who took Tea with us, and remained part of the Evening here— My Son and his wife, Elizabeth C. Adams, and her brothers Joseph, and Hull, with Mr. Glück, were also here as Evening visitors. I visited this morning the Office Room, in the Farm house, where the Library, given by my Father, to the Town of Quincy is still deposited though to be soon transferred to the new Town House and I borrowed, several Volumes, of the Work by Dupuis, entitled, Origine de tous Les Cultes, ou Religion Universelle, par Dupuis Citoyen François, published at Paris, L’An III. De La République, Une et Indivisible. with the motto Liberté, Égalité, Fraternité— not one person in ten thousand, in France at this day, knows, that this was in the year 1795, when among the Revolutions of the time, when the Christian Calendar had been abolished by the National Convention of France, and the epoque of the French Republic had been substituted in the stead of the Christian era— The Era, of the Republic one and indivisible, was very soon exchanged, for that of the Empire, and the Christian Era was restored in 1804, ten years before the restoration of the monarchy— There are some written notes, by my Father, to the Preface and first pages of Dupuis. I have taken the Book out with the purpose of reading it through.

I had a more quiet night than those of several preceding days— I was able to walk, round the short Square before dinner. Our Coachman Albert Putnam, took leave of me
this day and departed, Another has come to take his place his name is Wheeler, and we rode this Evening to Braintree returning by the way of Bents Point— Mrs. Charles Adams went this morning to Boston but neither she nor her husband were here this Evening— Their Son John Quincy came in their stead— Her daughter Louisa was expected and returned from her visit to Lenox— Miss Cutts was also expected but did not come.

This was the day of the monthly meeting of the Massachusetts Historical Society—but I did not attend it, having had a very indifferent nights rest— I had a professional visit from Dr. Woodward who modified some of his prescriptions— I walked round the long Square in a warm Summer day, suffering from cold. I had a visit also from Mrs. Fairfield who brought a Life of her Son the Poet, for whose works she was soliciting subscriptions as long as he lived, and now derives her subsistence, by peddling about the world his life. In the afternoon I rode with my wife, Mrs. John and Mrs. Charles Adams round Milton returning by the way of the Quarries.

Commencement Day at Cambridge—to which Mrs. John and Mrs. Charles Adams with their two daughters went. The two young Ladies remained at Cambridge at the Presidents House Mr. Everetts, the mothers returned home this Evening about nine oclock— I walked up to my sons House after dinner, and was sitting with him, when I was called home, by a
visit from Mr. Degrand, accompanied by two young Ladies one of whom he introduced by the name of Miss Nash of Boston, the other by a name which I do not recollect belonging to Virginia, and visiting Boston as a stranger. They took tea with us, and remained until nearly nine oclock in the Evening—

This was the day after Commencement at Cambridge there celebrated by the annual Exhibition of the Boylston Prize Declamations and by the delivery of an Oration before the Phi Beta Kappa Society— Our two young ladies, remained at Cambridge not to hear the Prize Declamations but to hear the Oration of Mr. George. P. Marsh the member of Congress from Vermont, before the Phi Beta Kappa Society. The usual annual performance is of a Poem in addition to the Oration— That however was omitted this year and the Oration itself though an eloquent and learned Discourse appears to have not quite so satisfactory to the audience, as has been for several preceding years—The young ladies returned home this evening. Mr. Ezekiel Bacon of Utica N.Y. paid me a long morning visit, and dined with my sons wifeon the Hill— My Son himself attended the Phi Beta Kappa Meeting at Cambridge and returned with my Granddaughters— I took a short walk before dinner—and in the evening I ride with my wife, in which we missed the road so as to cross the Granite Bridge to Dorchester in consequence of which we were compelled to return over the Neponset Bridge— Mrs. Frothingham, came out from Boston, and dined with her sister, as did also Mrs. John Adams. My son and his wife were here this Eveg.

I dined, at my Son’s House, with Mr. Wheaton heretofore a Reporter of Decisions of the Supreme Court of the United States, appointed by me in the year 1827 Chargé D’Affairs of the United States at the Court of Denmark, subsequently appointed I believe by Mr. Van Buren Minister Plenipotentiary of the Court of Russia at which Court he has been for the last ten years residing as Minister; and has recently returned with his family, to his own Country. He resides at Providence in the State of Rhode Island and is now on a visit to Boston. He came out, with my Son in the Railway Cars at a quarter before three and returned in the Evening Cars, which went from here quarter after six. I took a ride with my Wife and Mrs. John Adams to Braintree. There was a visitor who came while I was at my son’s house, and said he would come again tomorrow— My own condition differs not materially from day to day— I have received a Letter from Wm. Slade, dated at Saratoga Springs the 23d. of this month, with a Circular to the friends of popular Education in the United States, containing the Constitution of the Board of National Popular Education of which Mr. Slade is a general Agent, and for which he request my aid and cooperation To this Letter, I must return an elaborate answer which I commenced this day, but which I know not whether I shall ever be able to finish—

Miss Cutts arrived last evening from Mr. Hubbard’s Connecticut. I walked round the long square, and in the afternoon rode with my Wife and Mrs. Charles Adams, and Miss Cutts over Milton Hill, where we stopped at the Summer residence of the Revd. Mr. Lothrop Pastor of the Brattle street Church and left an
invitation to him from my Son to dine with him next Monday in company with a Class-mate of them both, now a visitor here from Louisiana. Isaac Hull, and Joseph Harrod, were here in the Evening— There were two persons who called on me this day one named Joyce, from Bangor in the state of Maine and the other Spencer Atherton who was a mendicant, for his brother, a mechanic who has suffered much from ill health and other misfortunes—

Almost every member of the family was this day complaining of indisposition, from which I almost alone was exempt. The Reverend Mr. Augustus Whitney settled as Pastor of a Congregational Church at Brighton and second son of the Revd. Peter Whitney, Minister of the Congregational Church at Quincy preached in exchange with Mr. Lunt. His morning text, was Psalm 37.37. “Mark the perfect Man, and behold the upright for the end of that man is peace.” And his Afternoon text was from Habackuk 2.3. [“]Though it tarry wait for it” This is only part of the whole of which is [“]for the vision is yet for an appointed time, but at the end it shall speak and not lie though it tarry wait for it, because it will surely come, it will not tarry”— The whole verse is very striking and the portion of it selected by Mr. Whitney is a theme of great significance, well expounded—which I thought it was by Mr. Whitney— He dined with us, though I was obliged to leave him immediately after dinner, for short repose before repairing to the afternoon meeting— We had no evening visitors, and I retired at an early hour

The beautiful Summer weather continues with cool and dewy nights. We have the account
of the death of a highly distinguished Citizen a Native of Amherst Massachusetts, but an inhabitant of the State of New York, long a member of Congress from that State and recently its Governor, in expectancy a Candidate for election as President of the United States, and whose decease will probably modify very considerably the canvass for that election— He died at his residenceof apoplexy. I took a ride this afternoon with my wife Mrs. John Adams and Miss Cutts. We had evening visits from President Quincy and the Rev Waterston—

The fine weather continues, and the state of my health during the day depends upon the degree of rest that I get by sleep in the night. This differs from one night to another, and from causes, which I am unable to anticipate or account for. I find it more and more difficult to take morning walks, and have almost given them up. My time is almost exclusively occupied in reading and in addition to the . . . of Herodotus, with whom I have not yet concluded, I have now undertaken to read the Origine de tous les Cultes, ou Religion Universelle par Dupuis Citoyen Francois— I commented upon the first part of the second Volume but I find him, growing so dull as I proceed that I fear I shall not read him through. And so I am commencing on another writer much of the same complexion an English author groping for vestiges of the Natural History of the Creation which my Son, has borrowed for me from the Boston Athenaeum— I rode this afternoon, with Mrs. John and Mrs. Charles Adams, to Braintree returning by the Railway through the Quarries. My Son and his wife were here, and the day closed with a mild Summer Eveg.
